Images in the movie channeled evolutionary theory and abstract art, depicting roaring dinosaurs, vibrating shapes and dancing brooms. Everything was set to classical music and blasted over the new Fantasound system, whose volume could apparently reach 165 decibels — enough, The New Yorker reported at the time, to “kill many elderly members of the audience, knock the others cold and deafen the survivors for life.” The magazine continued: “Don’t worry about it, though. title: How Should Racial Slurs in Literature Be Handled in the Classroom?
description: We look at whether the school context — the student body, teachers and larger community — should affect the way that books addressing race and racism are taught.
content: Have you ever been assigned to read a book that included racial slurs? How was that material introduced to you by your teacher? Were students given instructions for how to handle the racial slur when reading aloud? How did you feel and react when engaging with that content?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden Taps Pete Buttigieg for Transportation Secretary
description: Mr. Buttigieg would bring a younger voice to the cabinet and add to its diversity as its first openly gay member.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will nominate Pete Buttigieg to be secretary of transportation, Mr. Biden’s transition team announced Tuesday, selecting a former mayor of South Bend, Ind., and former opponent who would bring a younger voice to the cabinet and add to its diversity as its first openly gay member.

title: What is a nor’easter, exactly?
description: The storms can produce dangerous conditions such as power outages, icy roads and fallen trees
content: The word “nor’easter” usually elicits images of streets blanketed in heaps of snow and power lines defeated by intense winds. But what, exactly, makes a storm a nor’easter?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can Any A.F.C. Team Catch the Chiefs?
description: Sure, Kansas City (12-1) is flawed, but its closest challengers have a long way to go to usurp a Super Bowl berth.
content: The only real danger to the Kansas City Chiefs in the playoffs will be the Chiefs themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Even as vaccines show promise, the coronavirus is continuing to surge across Europe.

title: Paul Farmer Is Awarded the $1 Million Berggruen Prize
description: The medical anthropologist won the prize, which is given to “thinkers whose ideas have profoundly shaped human self-understanding and advancement.”
content: Paul Farmer, a medical anthropologist who has fought for stronger public health care infrastructure around the world, has been named the recipient of the 2020 Berggruen Prize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Felder
title: Time to Break Out the Lipstick
description: At the end of a socially distanced year, simply having the excuse to put on some makeup, like lip color, feels like a cause for celebration.
content: Like so many things this year, holiday get-togethers — perhaps attended on Zoom, possibly in leggings hidden from the computer screen — don’t look all that much like a traditional seasonal gathering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Mother Teresa Sings, in Drag and With Doubts
description: In Heather Christian’s “I Am Sending You the Sacred Face,” the saint of Calcutta vogues and lip-syncs and broods on the nature of selflessness.
content: Theater in Quarantine, a company that since March has been streaming experimental works from its founder’s closet, turns the constraints of its odd conditions into a marvelous style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Martin
title: Jack Steinberger, Nobel Winner in Physics, Dies at 99
description: Dr. Steinberger shared the prize in 1988 for expanding understanding of the neutrino, a staggeringly ubiquitous subatomic particle.
content: Jack Steinberger, who shared the 1988 Nobel Prize in Physics for expanding understanding of the ghostly neutrino, a staggeringly ubiquitous subatomic particle, died on Saturday at his home in Geneva. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What to Wear Next Year
description: The last shows of the season, from Saint Laurent, Alexander McQueen and Bottega Veneta, offered some ideas. Loungewear, meet life.
content: The spring 2021 fashion season, which began with the promise of normalcy in the form of Jason Wu’s show on a roof in front of a live audience back in September, finally came to an end in mid-December. It closed with the triple-header of a Bottega Veneta show bathed in eerie green light, an Alexander McQueen mini-film set in the graveled, muddy banks of the Thames, and a Saint Laurent show on the dunes of an unnamed desert, beamed over the brand’s social media channels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: In its last currency report, Trump administration labels 2 countries currency manipulators.
description: The Trump administration on Wednesday labeled Vietnam and Switzerland as currency manipulators, accusing them for the first time of improperly intervening in foreign exchange markets and setting off a new economic confrontation with two trading partners.

content: The economic upheaval caused by the pandemic is making this a very unusual holiday season.

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Suspect Is Charged With Murder Over Japan Animation Studio Fire
description: Prosecutors accused Shinji Aoba in connection with a blaze in Kyoto last year that killed 36, making it the country’s deadliest attack in decades.
content: TOKYO — Japanese prosecutors on Wednesday charged a man with arson and murder in connection with a fire last year that killed 36 at an animation studio in Kyoto, the country’s deadliest attack in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Counting on Biden, M.T.A. Shifts From Doomsday Budget to a Wishful One
description: New York’s transportation agency is expected to pass a stopgap budget that omits the draconian cuts transit officials have threatened in recent months.
content: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has warned for months that the agency would be forced to make draconian cuts, including slashing New York City’s subway service by 40 percent, as the pandemic plunged the nation’s largest public transit agency into its worst financial crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: My 50-Pound Bag of Flour Is Gone. My Sanity Remains.
description: Turns out, all I needed to survive lockdown was sourdough.
content: For a few innocent weeks about 10,000 years ago, at the dawn of the quarantine era of 2020, my Instagram feed and perhaps yours, too, was suddenly overrun with images of impossibly lovely loaves of homemade bread. It was one of the first social-media show-off fads of the pandemic; with everyone stuck at home, cut off from gym mirrors and airplane wings at sunset, bread-making virtuosity emerged in certain circles as the hottest new way to show everyone online how much better you were than everyone else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: China Charges Hong Kong Activists Caught Fleeing to Taiwan
description: The group has been denied access to lawyers hired by their families, raising fears in Hong Kong.
content: HONG KONG — Ten Hong Kong activists who were captured at sea while trying to flee to Taiwan in August were charged in mainland China on Wednesday with illegal boundary-crossing offenses that could put some of them behind bars for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Nursing home residents and staff are beginning to receive the vaccine.
content: The U.S. is moving to the next phase of its mass vaccination campaign as nursing home residents and staff are beginning to receive their shots.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Effective Is the Mask You’re Wearing? You May Know Soon
description: A C.D.C. division is working with an industry standards group to develop filtration standards — and products that meet them will be able to carry labels saying so.
content: More than 100,000 varieties of face masks are currently for sale. They come in silk, cotton and synthetics; with filters and without; over-the-head and over-the-ears. They have sparkles and sunflowers; friendly greetings and insults; cartoon characters and teeny reindeer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Soccer Will Run Trials on Concussion Substitutes in 2021
description: The move follows growing concern about the long-term effects of head injuries and the often-rushed treatment players receive.
content: Soccer leagues and tournaments around the world will be allowed to experiment with concussion substitutes starting in January, the body that oversees the sport’s rules announced Wednesday. The change is the most tangible action to be taken by soccer leaders amid growing concerns about the effects of head injuries at all levels of the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: ‘Like a Hand Grasping’: Trump Appointees Describe the Crushing of the C.D.C.
description: Kyle McGowan, a former chief of staff at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and his deputy, Amanda Campbell, go public on the Trump administration’s manipulation of the agency.
content: ATLANTA — Kyle McGowan, a former chief of staff at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and his deputy, Amanda Campbell, were installed in 2018 as two of the youngest political appointees in the history of the world’s premier public health agency, young Republicans returning to their native Georgia to dream jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Nikki Giovanni, Finding the Song in the Darkest Days
description: Part of the Black Arts Movement in the 1960s, part of a Biden campaign ad in 2020, she has never stopped writing.
content: Over the course of her 52-year career, Nikki Giovanni has written 12 children’s books and eight nonfiction books, and she has released 10 spoken word albums. But the genre for which she is best known is poetry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: After personal threats over a local mask mandate, the Dodge City, Kansas, mayor resigns.
description: The emails Joyce Warshaw received as mayor of Dodge City, Kan., were hostile enough last month, when the city was merely considering passing a mask mandate.

title: From Voter Fraud to Vaccine Lies: Misinformation Peddlers Shift Gears
description: Election-related falsehoods have subsided, but misleading claims about the coronavirus vaccines are surging — often spread by the same people.
content: Sidney Powell, a lawyer who was part of President Trump’s legal team, spread a conspiracy theory last month about election fraud. For days, she claimed that she would “release the Kraken” by showing voluminous evidence that Mr. Trump had won the election by a landslide.
source.name: The New York Times

title: It Took Mitch McConnell Six Weeks
description: With its surreal defiance, the Republican Party has established a new normal for anti-democratic behavior.
content: Early this week, electors in 50 states and Washington, D.C., formally chose Joe Biden as the next president of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: As China Tracked Muslims, Alibaba Showed Customers How They Could, Too
description: The website for the tech titan’s cloud business described facial recognition software that could detect members of a minority group whose persecution has drawn international condemnation.
content: As the Chinese government tracked and persecuted members of predominantly Muslim minority groups, the technology giant Alibaba taught its corporate customers how they could play a part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich
title: We Asked: Why Does Oreo Keep Releasing New Flavors?
description: The brand’s strategy is stunning in its simplicity.
content: The team of people who come up with limited-edition Oreo flavors and collaborations is a half-dozen strong and extremely secretive. Their privacy is so tightly guarded, said Justin Parnell, the senior director of the Oreo brand, that he could not even reveal the team’s name.

title: ‘Goodbye, Dragon Inn’: The Last Picture Show in Taipei
description: Tsai Ming-liang’s 2003 movie watches moviegoers as they watch a martial-arts classic inside a cavernous theater.
content: A sparse audience attends the last show in a cavernous movie house. Now all the more poignant for being streamed, Tsai Ming-liang’s 2003 “Goodbye, Dragon Inn,” newly restored, is a love letter to cinema and also cinemas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Closes Out Wild Year as All Eyes Focus on Bond-Buying Program
description: The central bank’s meeting will wrap up Wednesday, as the Fed stares down a bifurcated economic outlook.
content: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve is wrapping up what might be the most activist year in its history with a final scheduled policy meeting this week, one at which it is expected to leave interest rates at rock bottom and to signal continued willingness to help the economy through the challenging pandemic era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: A Portraitist Whose Subjects Are All in Her Head
description: A major new exhibition at Tate Britain in London puts the spotlight on Lynette Yiadom-Boakye, an artist who paints enigmatic Black characters of her own invention.
content: The British artist Lynette Yiadom-Boakye is a committed painter of people. Every piece she shows is, on first impression, a portrait — a careful study of one person, or, at most, a small group, with little to distract from their presence and force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Hundreds of Religious Leaders Call for End to L.G.B.T.Q. Conversion Therapy
description: The declaration, spearheaded by the Global Interfaith Commission on LGBT+ Lives, also calls for an end to violence and criminalization against L.G.B.T.Q. people.
content: In a show of unity aimed at fighting for the rights of L.G.B.T.Q. people, more than 370 international spiritual leaders have signed a declaration demanding a global ban on disputed conversion therapy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Jones
title: Pantomimes, an annual British cultural institution, are canceled.
description: The pantomime — merry, family-friendly musical comedy shows which take top billing at theaters throughout December — remains a peculiarly British tradition. It is nominally a children’s Christmas show based on a fairy tale such as “Sleeping Beauty,” “Cinderella” or “Jack and the Beanstalk” to which music-hall elements are added. Those include the dame (an actor in drag, who usually has a penchant for sexual innuendo), song-and-dance routines with topical lyrics, slapstick, in-jokes, call-and-response (“Oh no it isn’t!” “Oh yes it is!”) and familiar celebrity guest stars.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘This Is Who I Am’ Review: Cooking With Dad, Remotely
description: A son in New York and a father in the West Bank prepare a favorite family recipe. Longing and resentment are in the mix, too.
content: There is nothing like a recipe from someone you love to stoke the memories. You pluck it from the leaves of the cookbook — or, if you’re neater than I am, maybe from a recipe file — and instantly they’re there with you in the kitchen, at least in your mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Viet Thanh Nguyen
title: What the Asian-American Coalition Can Teach the Democrats
description: Its ability to form a solid majority around a shared politics despite its many differences is a model for the party — and the nation.
content: In coalition politics, every part of the coalition matters, especially when elections are close. For Democrats, Asian-Americans are suddenly crucial: They are the fastest-growing racial or ethnic group in the U.S. electorate, constituting 4.7 percent of the voting population — enough to make a difference in the presidential contest in Georgia, where Joe Biden won by some 12,000 votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: 2020: A Year in Fitness Like No Other
description: The novel coronavirus crept into and transformed every aspect of our lives, including the way we work out.
content: This year, the novel coronavirus crept into and transformed every aspect of our lives, including our fitness. In countless ways — some surprising, and a few beneficial and potentially lasting — it altered how, why and what we need from exercise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Court Finds 14 Guilty of Aiding Charlie Hebdo and Anti-Semitic Attacks
description: The accused were sentenced to between four years and life imprisonment for their roles in the 2015 attacks on a kosher supermarket and the magazine that killed 17 people.
content: PARIS — A French court on Wednesday found 14 defendants guilty of aiding in the terrorist attacks that killed 17 people in January 2015, including 10 people at the offices of the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, which had published cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kasia Pilat
title: 19 Recipes Our Food Staff Cooked on Repeat in 2020
description: Spotify has its end-of-year lists, and NYT Cooking has one, too: Reporters and editors shared their go-to recipes.
content: At the end of each year, Spotify releases personalized lists of the songs and artists that users listened to most over the last 12 months. There’s no algorithm to count exactly how many times the Food staff made the recipes below in 2020, but consider it the NYT Cooking version of the streaming giant’s end-of-year recap. Among the greatest hits: cheesy pan pizza, Momofuku bo ssam, and, of course, the year’s sleeper hit, Mark Bittman’s No-Knead Bread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor, Mihir Zaveri and Maria Jimenez Moya
title: Hundreds of flights are canceled, and Amtrak modifies service.
description: Transportation companies were altering operations, and officials were warning drivers to take extra care on the roads.
content: Hundreds of flights were canceled, rail service was suspended and driving on some busy roads was restricted as a snowstorm hit the East Coast on Wednesday and complicated holiday travel plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: Are We Ready to Laugh About Covid-19? A British Sitcom Hopes So
description: With ‘Pandemonium,’ the BBC is betting that an audience will find humor in reliving the ordeals of a very awful year.
content: A British family is walking along a frigid beach, treating a fall vacation like it’s a restaurant entree everyone wants to send back to the kitchen. The whole expedition is a lame Plan B. The Jessups were originally going to Disneyland, followed by three days of hiking at Yosemite. Then the coronavirus struck and sunny California was out of the question. Now the clan is making do in Margate, a forlorn British seaside town that peaked decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink and Christina Anderson
title: As cases surge and criticism swells, Sweden rethinks its response.
description: Since the pandemic began, a debate has raged both inside and outside of Sweden over how to curb the virus. As other countries went into lockdown in the spring, Sweden stayed open out of concern that keeping everyone holed up at home would have long-term detrimental effects on children and adults and could lead to depression, suicide, postponed health care and job losses.

description: Mr. Burrell, who has maintained his innocence, was 16 when an 11-year-old was killed by a stray bullet. The case posed challenges for Senator Amy Klobuchar during her presidential campaign.
content: Myon Burrell, 34, was released from a state prison on Tuesday after the Minnesota Board of Pardons commuted his life sentence in a murder case that angered advocates of criminal justice reform and hampered Senator Amy Klobuchar’s presidential campaign.

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden to Pick Brenda Mallory to Run White House Environment Office
description: The office, the Council on Environmental Quality, is expected to have an expanded focus on environmental justice under Ms. Mallory, an environmental lawyer.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. has chosen Brenda Mallory, an environmental lawyer who spent more than 15 years working in the federal government under both Republican and Democratic presidents, to lead the Council on Environmental Quality, according to two people close to the Biden transition team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Five Minutes of Beethoven
description: What emotions, images or ideas does this piano sonata evoke for you?
content: Beethoven was born 250 years ago this month and The Times is celebrating. In “5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Beethoven,” Times music editors and other experts invite you to  “listen to the best of the stormy, tender work of the composer who changed music.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinne Purtill
title: How to Revive the Economy, and When to Worry About All That Debt
description: A group of experts gathered to debate the priorities for economic policy with the end of the pandemic (seemingly) in sight.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has taken a brutal toll on the U.S. economy. Job losses resulting from the health crisis wiped out years’ worth of gains, hitting women, people of color and lower-paid workers already vulnerable to economic swings the hardest. An estimated 60 percent of businesses — about 100,000 individual establishments — that closed their doors temporarily as a result of Covid-19 have shut down for good, and more may follow in the months to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Santa Tests Positive for Virus After Photo Session With 50 Children
description: A husband and wife who dressed up as Santa and Mrs. Claus for an annual Christmas parade and tree-lighting ceremony in Georgia learned three days after the festivities that they had the coronavirus, officials said.
content: A Georgia couple who dressed up as Santa and Mrs. Claus for an outdoor photo session that was attended by about 50 children last week learned that they had tested positive for the coronavirus three days after the event, the county’s top elected official said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: China Brings Moon Rocks to Earth, and a New Era of Competition to Space
description: The Chang’e-5 mission’s success highlights the progress of China’s space program, and growing rivalry with the United States.
content: China may have been a latecomer to the moon, but when its capsule full of lunar rocks and soil returned to Earth early Thursday, it set the stage for a new space race over the coming decades. content: As Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine is rolled out across the U.S. and Moderna’s moves closer to gaining emergency approval, financiers are — naturally — seeking ways to profit. As The Times’s Kate Kelly reports, one popular path runs through the normally unsexy business of medical freezers.

description: Drops in November and October raise questions about how retailers are faring in the all-important holiday shopping season.
content: Consumer spending has been one of the few bright spots in the pandemic-battered economy. Since the spring, Americans have spent more each month even in the face of mounting job losses, political turmoil and recurring virus outbreaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: No Scrooge Here: Johnson Resists ‘Canceling’ Christmas to Stem Coronavirus
description: Britain’s prime minister has stuck by a pledge to lift restrictions on gatherings between Dec. 23 and 27 despite growing calls to  keep the measures in place as cases surge.
content: LONDON — In a year of hard decisions about how to confront the coronavirus, perhaps none has proved as anguished for Prime Minister Boris Johnson as whether to ban Britons from getting together for a little Christmas cheer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: America, We Have a Problem

content: As the pandemic has forced theater companies to reinvent themselves as digital creators, colleges and even high schools have delivered some of the most innovative projects. author: By Jon Pareles
title: ‘Break It All’ Celebrates the Oppositional Energy of Latin Rock
description: A new six-part Netflix series explores half a century of music under pressure.
content: Latin America has taken rock seriously. Seriously enough for governments to suppress it. Seriously enough for bands to sing about political issues, societal troubles and the spirit of rebellion. Seriously enough for fans to risk arrests and beatings to see a concert. While Latin rock can be thoroughly entertaining — catchy, playful, rambunctious, over the top — it rarely settles for being mere entertainment. There’s often far more going on behind the melody, rhythm and noise.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 4 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: Julie Mehretu’s vibrant colors; Minjung Kim’s gray and black ink paintings; Jean Katambayi Mukendi’s “Quarantaine” drawings; and Bosco Sodi’s clay spheres.
content: Julie Mehretu’s work has grown steadily stronger, especially over the last few years. It helped to eliminate the fussy layers of finely drawn architectural elevations, planning grids and weather maps that cramped her large canvases’ style, scale and apocalyptic mood, and to work more loosely by hand. This much was evident in the largely grisaille efforts in her 2016 show at Marian Goodman, where a new softness of line prevailed. It’s even more apparent in “about the space of half an hour,” her latest show at the gallery, whose title, from the Book of Revelation, refers to the short silence between the breaking of the Seventh Seal and God’s unleashing of the Final Judgment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Makes You Think 2021 Will Be Better?
description: Most of the issues that made 2020 feel like a horror story will roll along with us into the new year.
content: I’m not a Debbie Downer. Far from it. I’m usually an optimist who pushes for hope in the most dire of circumstances. However, when I hear friends talk about how the new year and Joe Biden’s presidency will answer our collective prayers and cleanse our collective palate from 2020’s unrelenting onslaught of pain and misery, I can’t help but feel skeptical.

Will we spend a day inside in our pajamas? Surely there’ll be sledding, snowmen and snow angels. An unexpected departure from the norm, a disruption of the rhythms of the week.

title: The Best of ‘This American Life’: 25th Anniversary Episodes
description: The show pioneered a new form of audio narrative journalism. Listen to some classics selected by the show’s host, Ira Glass.
content: When the public radio show I host went on the air 25 years ago, I was firmly against publicity photos. They were anti-radio, I’d tell anyone willing to listen to my little rant on the subject. Better not to be seen. Better to be a voice. A presence. Hearing Howard Stern has a power that seeing him does not. Ditto Rush Limbaugh or Terry Gross or anyone who knows what they’re doing on the mic. Why give up invisibility, which makes radio so powerful?
source.name: The New York Times
